name: Agrimony
description: A traditional healing herb for the digestive system and wound healing.
usage: Infusion of leaves; also used as a gargle for throat issues.

name: Alfalfa
description: Extremely deep roots draw up minerals; acts as a 'vitamin bomb' for the blood.
usage: Consumed as sprouts, leaf tea, or powder.

name: Aloe Vera
description: The inner gel is highly cooling and soothing to internal and external tissue.
usage: Gel applied topically; juice taken internally for gut lining repair.

name: Angelica
description: A warming herb that stimulates digestion and circulation in the pelvic region.
usage: Decoction of the root; often used in liqueurs for digestion.

name: Arnica
description: A premier remedy for trauma, bruising, and muscle soreness.
usage: Applied topically as a cream or oil. NEVER apply to broken skin or ingest (except homeopathically).

name: Ashwagandha
description: A premier Ayurvedic adaptogen that builds 'ojas' (vitality) and calms the nervous system.
usage: Powdered root decocted in milk or water; best taken at night for sleep.

name: Astragalus
description: A deep immune tonic that builds the 'Wei Qi' or protective shield of the body.
usage: Root slices simmered in soups or teas; best used long-term as a preventative.

name: Bacopa (Brahmi)
description: An ancient brain tonic that improves memory and cognitive function.
usage: Tincture or powder; supports the repair of neurons.

name: Barberry
description: Contains berberine; acts as a potent liver stimulant and antimicrobial.
usage: Decoction of bark or root; excellent for 'damp-heat' conditions.

name: Bayberry
description: A powerful circulatory stimulant and astringent.
usage: Often used in a gargle or as a powder in small doses to stimulate blood flow.

name: Bee Pollen
description: A complete food containing nearly all nutrients required by humans.
usage: Taken raw; start with 1 grain to test for allergic reaction, then increase.

name: Bilberry
description: Rich in anthocyanins that specifically protect the capillaries and eyes.
usage: Consumed as fresh fruit or standardized extract.

name: Birch Leaf
description: A gentle diuretic that helps flush uric acid from the system.
usage: Infusion of leaves; helps reduce water retention without depleting electrolytes.

name: Black Cohosh
description: The specific remedy for 'hot' symptoms of menopause and hormonal imbalance.
usage: Decoction or tincture; has an estrogen-modulating effect.

name: Black Walnut
description: High iodine and juglone content makes it a potent anti-parasitic.
usage: Tincture of the green hulls; usually part of a 'parasite cleanse'.

name: Blessed Thistle
description: A premier digestive bitter and 'galactagogue' (increases milk supply).
usage: Tea (very bitter) or capsules; stimulates the flow of gastric juices.

name: Blue Cohosh
description: A powerful uterine tonic used specifically to facilitate labor.
usage: Used ONLY under expert supervision during late-term pregnancy.

name: Boneset
description: Named for its ability to treat 'break-bone fever' (dengue); it is a powerful diaphoretic.
usage: Hot infusion; induces profuse sweating to break a fever.

name: Borage
description: The 'herb of courage'; it supports the adrenal glands during prolonged stress.
usage: Leaf tea or Seed Oil (rich in GLA).

name: Burdock Root
description: A deep blood purifier that moves stagnant lymphatic fluid and clears the skin.
usage: Decoction of the root; best used in combination with Dandelion root for liver support.

name: Butcher's Broom
description: A vasoconstrictor that improves the integrity of vein walls.
usage: Capsules or extract; particularly useful for circulatory issues in the legs.

name: Calendula
description: The 'sunshine herb' for the skin; highly anti-inflammatory and vulnerary (wound-healing).
usage: Infused oil for skin; tea for healing the digestive lining.

name: California Poppy
description: A gentle sedative and analgesic that does not cause dependency.
usage: Tincture or tea; milder than the Opium Poppy but effective for relaxation.

name: Cascara Sagrada
description: A potent 'stimulant' laxative that tones the muscles of the colon.
usage: Capsules or decoction; bark must be aged at least 1 year before use.

name: Cat's Claw (Una de Gato)
description: A powerful rainforest immune modulator with anti-inflammatory properties.
usage: Decoction of the inner bark; works by enhancing phagocytosis (immune engulfing).

name: Catnip
description: A gentle nervine and carminative that is excellent for children's ailments.
usage: Infusion; makes a very relaxing evening tea.

name: Cayenne Pepper
description: The 'king of stimulants'; it equalizes blood pressure and can stop a heart attack in progress.
usage: Powder in warm water or tincture; applied topically to stop bleeding (it doesn't sting on open wounds).

name: Celery Seed
description: Specifically targets the kidneys to excrete uric acid and other metabolic wastes.
usage: Infusion or capsules; a powerful 'alkalizing' herb for the joints.

name: Chamomile
description: A gentle, apple-scented flower that acts as a mild sedative and powerful digestive nervine.
usage: Infusion of dried flowers for tea, or used in a compress for localized skin inflammation.

name: Chaparral
description: One of the oldest plants on Earth; a powerful antioxidant and anti-tumor agent.
usage: Tincture or tea; has a very strong 'creosote' taste. Use with caution for liver health.

name: Chasteberry (Vitex)
description: A primary hormonal regulator that acts on the pituitary gland to balance progesterone.
usage: Tincture or capsules taken in the morning; requires 3-6 months for full effect.

name: Chickweed
description: A cooling, nutrient-rich herb that 'dissolves' fats and soothes itchy skin.
usage: Salves for skin; fresh in salads or tea for internal 'cooling'.

name: Chicory Root
description: A prebiotic rich in inulin that supports healthy gut flora and liver function.
usage: Roasted root used as a coffee substitute; decoction for medicinal use.

name: Cleavers
description: The premier lymphatic 'sweep'; it clears congestion in the lymph nodes.
usage: Fresh juice is best; cold infusion or tea also effective.

name: Clove
description: Highest antioxidant score of any plant; contains eugenol, a powerful numbing agent.
usage: Oil applied to gums for pain; powder in capsules for parasites.

name: Coltsfoot
description: Used for centuries as a premier remedy for chronic, spasmodic coughs.
usage: Infusion or smoking the leaves (historically) to open airways.

name: Comfrey (Knitbone)
description: Contains allantoin, which causes cells to multiply rapidly, speeding the healing of bones and skin.
usage: Poultice or salve for external use. Internal use is controversial due to pyrrolizidine alkaloids.

name: Corn Silk
description: A very gentle, soothing diuretic for the urinary tract.
usage: Infusion of fresh or dried silk; very safe for children and the elderly.

name: Cramp Bark
description: The specific remedy for smooth muscle cramps, especially in the uterus.
usage: Decoction or tincture; acts quickly to relax muscle spasms.

name: Damiana
description: A traditional Mexican aphrodisiac and tonic for the nervous system.
usage: Infusion or tincture; has a slightly euphoric and warming effect.

name: Dandelion Leaf
description: One of the best natural diuretics; unlike drugs, it is rich in potassium, so it doesn't deplete the body.
usage: Fresh in salads or steeped as a tea.

name: Dandelion Root
description: The premier liver tonic; it stimulates bile production and clears 'dampness'.
usage: Roasted root as coffee; decoction for medicinal strength.

name: Dong Quai
description: The 'female ginseng'; it builds blood and regulates the menstrual cycle.
usage: Decoction of the root; used to 'invigorate' and nourish the blood.

name: Echinacea (Purple Coneflower)
description: A premier immune stimulant that increases white blood cell count and activity.
usage: Tincture or decoction; most effective when taken at the very first sign of illness.

name: Elderberry
description: Contains powerful antiviral compounds that prevent viruses from entering cells.
usage: Syrup or tea; berries must be cooked before consumption to avoid toxicity.

name: Elderflower
description: A gentle diaphoretic that helps the body 'sweat out' a fever.
usage: Infusion; often combined with Peppermint and Yarrow for flu.

name: Eleuthero (Siberian Ginseng)
description: A powerful adaptogen that increases physical endurance and mental resilience.
usage: Tincture or decoction; safer for long-term use than Panax Ginseng.

name: Eyebright
description: Specifically targets the mucous membranes of the eyes and sinuses.
usage: Internal tea or carefully filtered external eye wash.

name: Fennel Seed
description: A cooling carminative that relaxes the digestive tract and dispels gas.
usage: Chewed raw or steeped as a tea.

name: Feverfew
description: The specific remedy for migraines; it inhibits the release of inflammatory prostaglandins.
usage: Fresh leaf eaten daily (with bread) or capsules; must be taken long-term for migraine prevention.

name: Garlic
description: Nature's most powerful antibiotic; it contains allicin which is active against bacteria, fungi, and viruses.
usage: Raw cloves crushed and eaten (allicin forms when crushed); oil for ear infections.

name: Gentian
description: The strongest digestive bitter; it 'wakes up' the entire digestive system.
usage: Tincture or tea taken 20 minutes before meals.

name: Ginger
description: A warming, pungent rhizome known for its potent anti-inflammatory and circulatory stimulating properties.
usage: Fresh juice for poultices, tea from sliced root, or grated into warm water for digestive support.

name: Ginkgo Biloba
description: Increases micro-circulation to the brain and extremities; acts as a potent antioxidant.
usage: Standardized extract (24% ginkgosides) is most effective.

name: Goldenseal
description: Contains berberine; a powerful 'natural antibiotic' that tones mucous membranes.
usage: Tincture or powder; should only be used for short periods (7-10 days).

name: Gotu Kola
description: The 'herb of longevity' that repairs connective tissue and enhances brain function without caffeine.
usage: Fresh leaves in salad or dried as tea; excellent for repairing skin and blood vessels.

name: Gravel Root (Joe Pye Weed)
description: A premier kidney and bladder herb used specifically to dissolve 'gravel' or stones by improving mineral metabolism.
usage: Decoction of the root. Best used in combination with Marshmallow root to soothe the passage of dissolved minerals.

name: Ground Ivy
description: A gentle but effective expectorant that helps clear heavy metal toxicity and chronic catarrh.
usage: Infusion of the leaves; particularly useful for drying up chronic 'runny' conditions in the head.

name: Guaiacum
description: A powerful stimulant and anti-inflammatory used to clear metabolic acid buildup from the joints.
usage: Tincture or decoction of the wood; acts as a 'cleansing' agent for the blood and joints.

name: Hawthorn Berry
description: The premier heart tonic; it strengthens the cardiac muscle and improves blood flow to the heart.
usage: Long-term use is necessary. Eaten as a berry, taken as a tea, or concentrated extract.

name: Hawthorn Leaf & Flower
description: Similar to the berry but more potent in its ability to dilate coronary arteries and reduce peripheral resistance.
usage: Steeped as a gentle tea; often combined with the berries for full cardiovascular support.

name: Hibiscus
description: A cooling, sour herb rich in Vitamin C and anthocyanins that acts as a natural ACE inhibitor.
usage: Cold or hot infusion; a refreshing 'refrigerant' tea that cools the body down in summer.

name: Holy Basil (Tulsi)
description: An 'elixir of life' that protects the body against chemical, physical, and emotional stress.
usage: Taken as a tea or tincture; used daily to support resilience and spiritual clarity.

name: Hops
description: A powerful sedative and bitter that slows down a hyperactive nervous system.
usage: Tea (very bitter) or a 'sleep pillow' stuffed with dried hops to inhale the volatile oils.

name: Horehound (White)
description: A traditional remedy for coughs; it thins the mucus so it can be coughed up easily.
usage: Often prepared as a syrup or candy; its bitter action also aids digestion.

name: Horse Chestnut
description: Contains aescin, which 'plugs' tiny holes in the capillaries to stop fluid leakage.
usage: Topical cream or standardized oral extract; raw seeds are toxic and must be processed.

name: Horsetail
description: Highest plant source of silica; it acts as a 'biological glue' for connective tissue and bone.
usage: Long decoction (20 mins) to extract minerals; also used as a tea for kidney support.

name: Huckleberry Leaf
description: Contains myrtillin, a compound that stabilizes blood sugar and supports the pancreas.
usage: Infusion of the leaves; a classic folk remedy for 'blood sugar balance'.

name: Hydrangea Root
description: A solvent root used specifically to dissolve calcium deposits in the kidneys and joints.
usage: Decoction; works effectively when combined with Gravel Root and Marshmallow.

name: Hyssop
description: A sacred herb for clearing the lungs and head; it possesses powerful antiviral properties.
usage: Tea or steam inhalation; particularly useful for 'hot' respiratory infections.

name: Irish Moss (Sea Moss)
description: A nutrient-dense seaweed providing 92 of the 102 minerals the body needs.
usage: Prepared as a gel and added to smoothies or used as a thickening agent in food.

name: Jamaican Dogwood
description: A very powerful pain reliever and sedative; it acts on the central nervous system.
usage: Used in very small doses (tincture) for acute pain management; should be monitored.

name: Juniper Berry
description: A powerful urinary disinfectant and diuretic that increases the glomerular filtration rate.
usage: Infusion or chewing 3-5 berries daily; avoid in cases of acute kidney inflammation.

name: Kava Kava
description: A traditional Pacific island herb that induces deep physical relaxation without clouding the mind.
usage: Traditionally prepared as a cold-water maceration or taken as a standardized extract.

name: Kelp
description: A rich source of organic iodine and minerals essential for thyroid hormone production.
usage: Consumed as powder, tablets, or added to food as a salt substitute.

name: Kudzu
description: A fast-growing vine whose root is used to treat addiction and cardiovascular issues.
usage: Decoction or standardized capsules; effectively reduces the 'reward' associated with addictive substances.

name: Lady's Slipper
description: A rare and powerful nervine for extreme nervous exhaustion and hysteria.
usage: Used sparingly as a tincture for acute nervous system crises.

name: Lavender
description: A versatile aromatic that calms the central nervous system and heals burned skin.
usage: Essential oil inhaled or applied (diluted) topically; flowers steeped for a calming tea.

name: Lemon Balm (Melissa)
description: A 'gladdening' herb that calms a hyperactive thyroid and inhibits viral replication.
usage: Infusion of fresh leaves is most potent; used topically for cold sores.

name: Lemongrass
description: A cooling, antifungal grass used to lower fevers and improve digestion.
usage: Refreshing tea taken to support the immune system and cool the body.

name: Licorice Root
description: A potent adrenal support and anti-viral that mimics the effect of corticosteroids without the side effects.
usage: Decoction or chew sticks. Caution: Can raise blood pressure in sensitive individuals if used excessively.

name: Lobelia (Indian Tobacco)
description: The 'thinking herb' that relaxes smooth muscle spasms and opens the respiratory tract.
usage: Often used as a tincture in very small 'catalytic' amounts with other herbs to increase their efficacy.

name: Maca Root
description: A Peruvian adaptogen that balances the endocrine system and increases stamina.
usage: Root powder added to food; improves energy levels by nourishing the adrenal glands.

name: Marshmallow Root
description: Highly mucilaginous; it coats and protects inflamed mucous membranes throughout the body.
usage: Cold water infusion (steeped overnight) is best to extract the mucilage without destroying it with heat.

name: Milk Thistle
description: Contains silymarin, which protects the liver from toxins and stimulates the regeneration of liver cells.
usage: Standardized extract (80% silymarin) or ground seeds taken in capsule form.

name: Motherwort
description: The 'heart protector' for mothers; it calms heart palpitations and strengthens the uterus.
usage: Tincture or tea; acts quickly to calm a 'pounding' heart caused by emotional distress.

name: Mullein
description: A premier respiratory tonic that softens impacted mucus and heals the lung tissue.
usage: Leaf tea for lungs; flower-infused oil for earaches. Filter tea carefully to remove tiny irritating hairs.

name: Myrrh
description: A powerful antiseptic and antimicrobial resin that stimulates white blood cell activity.
usage: Tincture used as a mouthwash or applied topically to infections. Highly effective for boggy, inflamed tissues.

name: Nettle Leaf
description: A nutrient powerhouse rich in iron and chlorophyll; it acts as a natural antihistamine.
usage: Strong infusion. To treat hay fever, it should be taken regularly before the season begins.

name: Nettle Root
description: Specifically targets the male reproductive system by inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to DHT.
usage: Decoction or standardized extract; used specifically for prostate health.

name: Oat Straw
description: One of the best tonics for 'feeding' the nervous system, rich in calcium and magnesium.
usage: Infusion of the green straw. It provides a steady, grounded energy rather than a stimulant spike.

name: Olive Leaf
description: Contains oleuropein, a potent antiviral and hypotensive agent.
usage: Tea or extract. It is particularly effective at lowering blood pressure naturally without side effects.

name: Oregano Oil
description: A 'heavy hitter' in the herbal world; it is a broad-spectrum antifungal and antibiotic.
usage: Used in very small amounts (1-2 drops) diluted in oil or water. Short-term use only.

name: Oregon Grape Root
description: A berberine-containing herb that stimulates liver function and clears the skin.
usage: Decoction or tincture. Excellent alternative to Goldenseal for chronic skin conditions.

name: Parsley
description: A strong diuretic and emmenagogue that flushes the kidneys and stimulates menstruation.
usage: Fresh juice or tea. Avoid large medicinal amounts during pregnancy as it can stimulate the uterus.

name: Passionflower
description: The specific remedy for 'circular thinking' and insomnia where the mind won't shut off.
usage: Infusion or tincture before bed. It calms the motor centers of the brain.

name: Pau D'Arco
description: A rainforest bark with powerful anti-cancer and anti-fungal properties.
usage: Decoction of the inner bark. It must be simmered for at least 15 minutes to be effective.

name: Peppermint
description: A refreshing carminative that relaxes the stomach muscles and dispels gas.
usage: Tea or essential oil (diluted) on the temples. Drink as a tea after meals for digestion.

name: Plantain (Broadleaf)
description: The 'drawing' herb; it pulls out toxins, stingers, and infections from the skin.
usage: Fresh 'spit poultice' for stings; tea for internal healing of the gut lining.

name: Pokeweed
description: A very powerful lymphatic stimulant; it 'kicks' the immune system into high gear.
usage: Use with extreme caution. One drop of tincture is often sufficient. Potentially toxic in high doses.

name: Quassia
description: The most bitter plant known; it is an incredible digestive tonic and parasiticide.
usage: Cold infusion of wood chips. Used as an enema for threadworms or taken orally to spark digestion.

name: Raspberry Leaf (Red)
description: The premier 'female tonic' containing fragarine, which tones the uterine muscles.
usage: Infusion. Highly recommended in the third trimester to facilitate a smoother labor.

name: Reishi Mushroom
description: The 'mushroom of immortality'; it modulates the immune system and calms the spirit.
usage: Decoction (simmer for 1-2 hours) or extract. It balances an overactive immune response.

name: Rhubarb Root (Turkey Rhubarb)
description: A powerful anthraquinone laxative that also has astringent properties for the gut.
usage: Decoction or powder. Use small doses for tonic effects or larger doses for a purge.

name: Rosemary
description: Increases blood flow to the head and improves peripheral circulation and memory.
usage: Infusion or culinary use. Using a rosemary rinse on the scalp stimulates hair follicles.

name: Sage
description: A cooling herb that dries up secretions, including sweat and breast milk.
usage: Tea or gargle. Excellent for night sweats associated with menopause.

name: Sarsaparilla
description: A potent 'blood purifier' rich in plant steroids that help balance hormones.
usage: Decoction. It binds to endotoxins in the blood and carries them out of the body.

name: Saw Palmetto
description: The specific remedy for the male reproductive system, particularly the prostate.
usage: Standardized extract of the fatty acids in the berries. Best for long-term prostate support.

name: Schisandra Berry
description: The 'five-flavor fruit' that supports all five yin organs and enhances liver detoxification.
usage: Decoction of the berries. It is a powerful adaptogen that improves physical endurance.

name: Scullcap (American)
description: One of the best herbs for nervous tension and tremors; it 'renews' the nerves.
usage: Infusion or tincture. It is a 'trophorestorative' for the nervous system.

name: Self-Heal (Heal-All)
description: A humble mint-family herb that stimulates the lymphatic system and heals wounds.
usage: Infusion or poultice. It is highly effective against the herpes simplex virus.

name: Senna
description: A powerful stimulant laxative that triggers peristalsis in the colon.
usage: Infusion (short steep). Should not be used for more than 7-10 days to avoid dependency.

name: Shepherd's Purse
description: The premier herb for stopping internal and external hemorrhaging.
usage: Fresh tincture is most effective. It acts as a powerful vasoconstrictor and styptic.

name: Slippery Elm
description: Contains high levels of mucilage that creates a protective layer over the entire GI tract.
usage: Powder mixed into a 'gruel' with water. It is so gentle it can be used as a primary food source during illness.

name: St. John's Wort
description: Known as 'bottled sunshine,' it heals nerve damage and lifts mild to moderate depression.
usage: Infused oil for topical nerve pain; tincture for internal mood support. Caution: Interacts with many medications.

name: Tea Tree
description: A powerful external-only antimicrobial that destroys bacteria, fungi, and viruses on contact.
usage: Essential oil applied topically (diluted) for sensitive skin. NEVER ingest.

name: Thyme
description: Contains thymol, a potent disinfectant that helps expel worms and clears the respiratory tract.
usage: Strong infusion or steam inhalation. Effective for 'spasmodic' coughs.

name: Turmeric
description: A premier anti-inflammatory that inhibits NF-kB and supports healthy liver detoxification.
usage: Root powder taken with black pepper and fat to increase curcumin absorption.

name: Uva Ursi (Bearberry)
description: Contains arbutin, which converts to hydroquinone in the urine to kill bacteria.
usage: Short-term use only (7 days). Best used in alkaline urine; avoid with highly acidic foods.

name: Valerian Root
description: A strong sedative that improves sleep quality by increasing GABA levels in the brain.
usage: Decoction or tincture before bed. Note: Small percentage of people feel 'wired' instead of sleepy.

name: White Willow Bark
description: The 'natural aspirin' containing salicin, which provides pain relief without gastric bleeding.
usage: Decoction. Slower acting than aspirin but the effects last much longer.

name: Wild Cherry Bark
description: A powerful sedative for the respiratory nerves; it stops an unproductive, irritating cough.
usage: Cold infusion or syrup. It 'quiets' the cough reflex to allow for rest.

name: Wild Yam
description: Contains diosgenin, which is a precursor to hormones and acts as a powerful antispasmodic.
usage: Decoction or topical cream. Excellent for relaxing smooth muscle tension in the pelvis.

name: Witch Hazel
description: A premier astringent that tightens distended veins and stops minor bleeding.
usage: Topical extract or distilled water. Used as a compress to shrink inflamed tissues.

name: Wood Betony
description: A grounding herb that 'draws the energy out of the head' and back into the body.
usage: Infusion. One of the best herbs for people who feel 'stuck in their head' or over-analytical.

name: Wormwood
description: An extremely bitter herb used primarily to expel intestinal parasites and stimulate the liver.
usage: Infusion (very short-term) or tincture. Its extreme bitterness sparks the entire digestive fire.

name: Yarrow
description: The 'master of the blood'it can stop a hemorrhage or move stagnant blood, as needed.
usage: Hot tea to induce sweating for fevers; powder topically to stop bleeding; cold tea for kidneys.

name: Yellow Dock
description: A blood tonic that improves iron absorption and stimulates bile flow from the liver.
usage: Decoction or syrup. It helps release iron stored in the tissues back into the bloodstream.

name: Yohimbe
description: A powerful stimulant that increases blood flow to the extremities and pelvic region.
usage: Standardized extract. Caution: Can cause heart palpitations, anxiety, and high blood pressure.

name: Yucca Root
description: Contains high levels of steroid-like saponins that reduce joint inflammation.
usage: Decoction or capsules. It acts as a natural 'detergent' for the joints, clearing debris.
